title: War hero James Simpson holds no fear as England head Down Under for historic Ashes clashes
text:

James Simpson has overcome challenges in his life that few could comprehend - so taking on Australia at rugby league in their own backyard holds no fear.

Simpson had both legs blown off when he triggered an explosive device while on duty for the Yorkshire Regiment 1st Battalion in Afghanistan 10 years ago.

He also lost three fingers and the muscle from his right forearm, but describes the experience as “life changing not life ending”.

It took him almost three years of rehabilitation to get used to his prosthetic legs, before he discovered wheelchair rugby league, an emerging, exciting and brutal form of the sport that aims to replicate the running game as closely as possible.

Simpson quickly progressed playing for his boyhood club Leeds Rhinos, earning selection for England and playing in the 2017 World Cup in France.

Now he is taking part in a ground-breaking Ashes trip Down Under that will see England play five matches in two weeks, including two tests against Australia.

(Image: INTERNET PICTURE)

England won their tour opening in North Queensland by 50 points and Simpson said: “It’s the first time it’s been done and certainly isn’t a jolly.

“We land, train, play and then fly to another city to play again.

“We beat Australia in the 2017 semi-finals but we know how tough it will be over there, especially with the crowds.

“They’re a tough team, a very rugby league-orientated team where you see a lot of the running game in their play.

“It’s a great test for us and I can’t wait.”

Simpson says wheelchair rugby league has helped changed his life from the moment he started training with the Rhinos.

(Image: PHILIP HAYNES 2017)

He said: “I had guys that were 12 telling me what to do in the chair.

“We laugh about it now but it was totally different for me and I’m the kind of person that if somebody knows more about something than me, then I’ll always listen to them.

“Coming from a military background where everybody is early 20s, it was a huge difference because you get people of all ages and backgrounds playing.

“Some of them have been disabled their whole lives and could tell me things about navigating life as a disabled person.

“It’s been a massive eye opener and just being in a wheelchair has made me more comfortable with myself and my injuries.

“Before I hardly used a wheelchair and wore my prosthetics all the time, but I’m a lot more comfortable with my new body now.”
description: The England star had his legs blown off while in Afghanistan with the Yorkshire Regiment 1st Battalion 10 years ago
